title: What will be Coinbase's end-of-day market capitalization on its first day of public trading?
possible_answers: More than $100 billion but less than $125 billion
Coinbase will not trade publicly before 30 October 2021
preds:
IMO, judging by the volumes, this could be current shareholders 'testing' the market. It's early in the day but may be an indication of a quieter opening than was expected? https://bit.ly/3mKkU6p & https://bit.ly/3gae7kV which shows a price creeping higher
@SE_Meyer

Strangely, under
https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/COIN:US
bloomberg lists 130.7m as the number of shares outstanding, which doesn't fit any of the previously circulating amounts of stocks.
Anyway, this doesn't necessarily have to be the final number, maybe there is some link to the direct listing procedure that makes shares outstanding increase with trading?
At 765.12USD per share, 130.7mn shares would exceed 100bn USD market cap, which is my best bet with new information, subject to change over the day. @bh4eh

https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/13/coinbase-is-unlike-any-market-debut-wall-street-has-ever-seen-.html
my head hurts trying to figure this one out.
according to the linked article 100bn is estimated fully diluted share value and would make it to 85 most valuable companies in US. IPO market caps are usually way below that so immediately we should be cautious. However peeps seem crazy about the crypto lately so probably more people will want to buy it than want to sell it on the first day so probably the price goes up (at least over the first day-eventually it probably goes down again)

Making a forecast on this question is like pushing against a piece of string; not very effective. There are too many opinions and not enough historic information on which to attempt a 'market valuation' based on traditional methods. This article, https://cnb.cx/3dXpTg1, and the one linked by @SE_Meyer (https://bit.ly/2OPcWfI) perhaps best describe the conundrum. We may know what the market thinks (and decides) in the next 36 hours depending on how many shares are put up for sale by the current shareholders. I'd suggest that most of the institutional, startup funders and private holders will hold on to the bulk of their shares and hence trading may be thin which could well exacerbate price action to the upside. I am already wincing at what this may do to my brier score.

@John-Baker  Thanks for your info and input. There's no doubt that Coinbase has a relatively small source of revenue streams albeit their intention for 2021 and ahead is extend the revenue streams from subscriptions (See Alesia Haas, Chief Financial Officer @ +/- 2:20 on https://bit.ly/3sYieEc) Q1 2021 estimate results were released  on 6/4/21 and beat total 2020 with revenues @ $1.8bn and net $730m - $800m (see https://bit.ly/322QVNp) On the release of the Q1 2021 the forward looking statement is interesting in that it references the volatility of crypto and BTC; see https://s27.q4cdn.com/397450999/files/doc_downloads/Q1'21-Coinbase-Earnings-Call-Transcript.pdf Current futures are asking around $525 (https://bit.ly/3mJgPiQ). If the reference price is 20% - 30% lower, that creates a vlauation around $100bn - $120bn Another comment of a few days ago estimates a valuation of $70bn-$90n (https://bit.ly/3a2npf3). IMHO, as long as BTC stays above $55k and ETH / ETH2 stays above $2k and the institutions continue to show interest in crypto , I'd expect a valuation of $100bn - $150bn. However, as I have said previously, with the 114.9m shares being listed by current shareholders, it all depends on how many are actually planning on selling on the 14th April. @SE_Meyer I see you have targeted a 'reference' or opening price of $500 and hence have increased your No 4 bucket too. I am not quite as optimistic as you.

UPDATE: Pre-IPO Coinbase futures contracts are trading for $493 as of April 8. Up from $458 on April 3 (https://ftx.com/trade/CBSE/USD). Very curious to see what the reference price will ultimately be. According to Axios, Coinbase offered in mid-February a private sale of 127,000 shares, which sold for $373. This valuation would equal $100.23 billion. Coinbase's $100 billion valuation represents a 78x price/sales multiple and is more than the Intercontinental Exchange, NASDAQ, and Euronext valuations combined ($94 billion). Coinbase received over 96% of its net revenue from transaction fees and commissions in 2020, indicating the company's revenue streams are not well diversified. If cryptocurrency prices continue to surge, Coinbase would expect to increase its 2021 revenue ($1.277 Billion in 2020). If cryptocurrency prices fall, however, Coinbase has few other revenue streams upon which the company can rely. Coinbase is capitalizing on the recent rabid investor appetite for all things crypto by listing now. Steadily declining crypto prices or increased competition may shake investor confidence in Coinbase being worth $100 billion, but there is little time left for that to occur. Private stock sales have indicated strong investor confidence and, as mentioned previously, a valuation approaching $100 billion. Furthermore, pre-IPO stock futures contracts for Coinbase are selling for $458 as of April 3. This is another data point that enables some price discovery. That would value Coinbase somewhere around $120 billion. Most book value analyses I've seen put Coinbase worth less than $75 billion, so I've left some room for that to occur. Every other price discovery data point I've seen has indicated a market valuation around $100-$120 billion. Only time will tell. As of April 2, Coinbase is reportedly going public on April 14, so I've assigned a 0% probability to "will not trade publicly before 30 October 2021."
updating based on latest understanding of company valuation

We don't really know anything - waiting for reference price
Keeping forecast the same
Essentially will come out ahead of it is anything other than between 100-150mm

UPDATE: Pre-IPO Coinbase futures contracts are trading for $493 as of April 8. Up from $458 on April 3 (https://ftx.com/trade/CBSE/USD). According to Axios, Coinbase offered in mid-February a private sale of 127,000 shares, which sold for $373. This valuation would equal $100.23 billion. Coinbase's $100 billion valuation represents a 78x price/sales multiple and is more than the Intercontinental Exchange, NASDAQ, and Euronext valuations combined ($94 billion). Coinbase received over 96% of its net revenue from transaction fees and commissions in 2020, indicating the company's revenue streams are not well diversified. If cryptocurrency prices continue to surge, Coinbase would expect to increase its 2021 revenue ($1.277 Billion in 2020). If cryptocurrency prices fall, however, Coinbase has few other revenue streams upon which the company can rely. Coinbase is capitalizing on the recent rabid investor appetite for all things crypto by listing now. Steadily declining crypto prices or increased competition may shake investor confidence in Coinbase being worth $100 billion, but there is little time left for that to occur. Private stock sales have indicated strong investor confidence and, as mentioned previously, a valuation approaching $100 billion. Furthermore, pre-IPO stock futures contracts for Coinbase are selling for $458 as of April 3. This is another data point that enables some price discovery. That would value Coinbase somewhere around $120 billion. Most book value analyses I've seen put Coinbase worth less than $75 billion, so I've left some room for that to occur. Every other price discovery data point I've seen has indicated a market valuation around $100-$120 billion. Only time will tell. As of April 2 (yesterday), Coinbase is reportedly going public on April 14, so I've assigned a 0% probability to "will not trade publicly before 30 October 2021."

As @nucleus pointed out (https://bit.ly/39CnBBq) the direct listing is due on 14 April. Confirmed by Coinbase at https://bit.ly/31Nwp2Z. For more info, see https://bit.ly/2OgqvV3 for the SEC listing. Jesse Powell of Kraken is very positive about Coinbase's direct listing (https://bloom.bg/3mgDbYs) and is planning a listing of Kraken in 2022. Powell also expects Coinbase to be valued at $100bn 'with a pop after that'.  Apropos Coinbase, as it is a direct listing, no new capital will be raised, no new shares will be issued, no intermediaries are involved and only current shareholders can sell shares as there is no lockup period. So, in reality, the price of a share at listing is determined by supply and demand and the 'reference price'. The reference rice is usually determined by the company's adviser and internal transactions. See the section about IOP v DLP here https://bit.ly/3sN4b4z. Looking at Coinbase's Mission Statement (https://bit.ly/3sNXHSR ) and the first paragraph of the company's website; "We are building the cryptoeconomy – a more fair, accessible, efficient, and transparent financial system enabled by crypto." and what is often held the views about the traditional financial structures and markets in the crypto sphere, it is not surprising that Coinbase has chosen the DLP route.  Coinbase will list 114.85m Class A shares at a maximum aggregate offering of $943m according to the SEC listing (https://d18rn0p25nwr6d.cloudfront.net/CIK-0001679788/cbfab060-8271-48dc-a12e-54b7416a71f9.pdf). Secondary private Nasdeq dealings a couple of months ago suggested the company would be worth $100bn at listing (https://bit.ly/2QjwxVH).  Bearing in mind the following:
i) The current 'boom' in crypto prices
ii) Coinbase earns fees from both transactions and subscriptions and storage, fees will rise as traded asset prices rise
iii) the company generated revenues of $1.3bn in 2020 and $527m (EBITA) (see Our Business Model by Alicia Haas at https://bit.ly/3sYieEc)
iv) continued acceptance of crypto and investment into by institutions
v) the company held $130m in BTC at Dec 2020 and $23.8m in ETR and $34m (+/- $188m) in internal HODL crypto
vi) the listing is less than 2 weeks away and there are now apparent cracks in the crypto world's prices It is feasible that company's A Class shares will trade on the 14th April in the upper estimates and value the company $120bn - $150bn. Without knowing the intentions of the current shareholders, estimating a price and hence a company valuation in a direct listing is a big ask. @SE_Meyer I see you are leaning towards the top end with a small forecast in the > $150bn.

@SE_Meyer
Private placement pushed back - https://bloom.bg/3r78yFP. Although the FED's last FOMC was quite dovish, markets are still a bit nervous and many day traders may have already spent their stimmies (US$1,400 'stimulus' cheques) by the time listing takes place. Hence a revised forecast.

Private Nasdaq placings can only provide a rough estimation but they do show what some are prepared to pay ahead of a listing - https://bit.ly/3eTUsVV and https://bit.ly/2QjwxVH One also has to ask the question, why would one take part in private placings unless there is a likelihood of an IPO?  @SE_Meyer you may find the above links interesting and seem to concur with your thinking
Moving some probability out of >150 and into the 2 lowest buckets, since this will be a direct listing, which (I think) means no lock up period.

There are some general profile statistics on Coinbase at the link below. I predict that the 2020 valuation will grow by 2-5x. This covers a few different outcomes, where I've distributed my forecast %. https://www.businessofapps.com/data/coinbase-statistics/

News says coinbase valuation sitting at $68B right now. May not be final valuation going into IPO as I understand there is no set date, Moving my results out of $100B+ answers and skewing far more towards $75-$100B with some towards <$75 as it could be a total flop or not gain much traction opening day based on a variety of factors larger than coinbase.

In a pre-IPO financing round Stripe (a payment service) collected 600mn USD and is now said to have a market cap of 95mn USD, plus be the most valuable FinTech in the world, exceeding even facebook's pre-IPO valuation.
Coinbase appears to be a "disruptor" company of the same species, makes me estimate a valuation in excess of 125bn USD on their first trading day.

Coinbase reportedly has a valuation of $90 billion on the private markets. IPO's have been popping lately - 38% on average in 2020, though many of those companies were not traded on a privately previously, so the pop may be from a lower starting point.  A 38% pop would take Coinbase into the 125-150 billion category.
https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/trends-in-ipo-pops-2021-03-04 Bitcoin is in the news, and the market is crazy, which definitely adds chance of a 50%+ pop, in the 150+ billion category

$90b private auction per news, +median day one pop was 20% in 2020, which will be further exacerbated by stimmy money (for example, deutsche bank survey says 50% of ages 25-34 planning to invest half of their stimulus), and coinbase has all the hallmarks of a meme stonk. Median expected outcome = $100b at open, +30% day one. So yeah, I think we'll probably be looking at a company with a $130b market cap off of $1.3b in revenue last year and only $322m net income. Sign of the times. Worth noting they have an estimated $53b worth of btc in cold storage (1m coins * 53k per at todays prices), but that's wildly different from $53b of cash on hand. Coinbase will do great on day one, but will get absolutely roasted as soon as btc returns to a more reasonable level (as in 2013 and 2017), or we're in a more general risk off environment.

As of March 8 2021, Coinbase is valued at ~90B in private auction. (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-03-08/coinbase-is-said-to-be-valued-at-90-billion-in-private-auction?sref=3REHEaVI)
This article also quotes sources that say the company will be listed before the end of March 2021, suggesting that value will be relatively stable.

News and "results" from private NASDAQ auctions showed valuation between 90B-100B USD. Adjusting my forecast higher to 100+ and off <75B. Still holding strong on 75-100 in case crypto sinks, tech sinks, markets overall sink.
I am a professional in this topic.

Given the current total market share (have to look up any meaningful figure), their standing in the market ("Coinbase Pro" for institutional investors) and the efficiency and success of new ICOs in the current boom cycle, Coinbase must be a money making machine.
However, the boom cycle could be short lived, and its end, if caught on the wrong foot, could cause Coinbase to scrap IPO/direct listing  plans this year altogether.
Other very large IPOs of fast growing so called FinTechs, such as Ant Financial, have been stopped in the eleventh hour spectacularly for regulatory reasons (although, in the Ant Financial, affiliate to Alibaba, there were other more political reasons linked to domestic Chinese efforts to publicize private wealth and corporations...), and unless Crypto currencies become even more mainstream via e.g. publicly traded ETFs, it will be hard to convince the SEC of a viable long-term sustainable business model. The SEC will have to think twice to prevent themselves from falling for the line of another big Ponzi scheme that could potentially burn dozens of billions of USD in saving account capital of the size of the Madoff scandal, where the SEC was accused of doing a poor job. Thus, a significant risk of not happening.
According to their S-1 form registration to the SEC, Coinbase doesn't even have a headquarter or post address, pretty unlikely for a potentially three digit billion USD company.
The S-1 form is not a final document, as suggested by "Subject to Completion, dated               , 2021. " within the prospectus.
https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1679788/000162828021003168/coinbaseglobalincs-1.htm Their direct listing according to current articles, however, appears very near.
https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/coinbase-valued-at-%24100-billion-as-its-ipo-approaches-2021-03-07 Coindesk cites a private auction offering to be the last occasion to buy ahead of the listing "later this month [March 2021]", and suggests a first price of more than 300USD or up to 100bn USD market cap is clearly within reach. Considering the experience of IPOs such as SNOW and ABNB, first trading days tended to end up in a frenzy or a "buying panic", so I suggest COIN will close higher than 125bn USD easily. The fact alone, that Coinbase was able to pick the direct listing procedure (the first major one done by a tech company was spotify, and the argument for which usually is cost saving through not paying investment banks for their IPO-related services) speaks for an enornous interest of investors and institutionals, and their demand for the stock from day 1.
https://www.coindesk.com/coinbase-value-nasdaq-private-market
Market cap will still be under 2 digits

Crypto currency seems to keep growing more popular every day.
https://cointelegraph.com/news/coinbase-reportedly-hits-pre-ipo-valuation-of-100-billion-in-private-auction
First forecast, gut feeling on minimal reading. Nasdaq valuation at $77B, but cannot find an intended IPO date anywhere.

Coinbase stock is going to be a "story stock" because people are enamored of cryptocurrencies and Coinbase is one of the major players in this space.  It is also a profitable company earning around $322 million for the year 2020 (source: Forbes; https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomtaulli/2021/02/26/coinbase-ipo-what-you-need-to-know/?sh=4f8f369415d6).  While much details of the IPO are not available yet, all sources indicate the market cap of Coinbase will exceed $100 billion which is less than 100 times 2020 sales.  Recently, many story stocks, such as Snowflake, Airbnb and a few others have doubled, tripled or even quadrupled their market cap on the first day of trading.  Unless the cryptocurrency markets totally collapse by the time the stock starts trading, Coinbase will be richly valued.  If the crypto markets collapse, all bets are off but that is unlikely to happen in the near future.  See also https://www.fool.com/investing/2021/02/26/should-you-buy-the-coinbase-ipo-here-are-the-key-f/

Would appear the valuation of shares has gone up in private market share sale. But demand might also be affected by overall market conditions which has seen some fluctuation due to rates driving tech stocks down. The giant rise of Bitcoin the past few weeks/months and announcements by large companies purchasing it does mean that interest is high in any compnay that deals with cryptocurrency. 
https://www.axios.com/coinbase-valued-100-billion-direct-listing-9b43e316-7ff7-4f6a-a1db-4dc2481a93ee.html

Coinbase made 322 m$ profit in 2020 
currently only third biggest , but american 
Crypto hype... strong increase first days and then steep decline

I am pretty sure Coinbase will be trading publicly before October because they're doing a direct listing so now that the SEC has published their S-1 I think they are pretty close with not a lot of other things to do. I'm not a finance guru so somebody tell me if I'm misunderstanding this Their last venture round in 2018 was at 8bn  granted the price and buzz around bitcoin has exploded since then 
the 100bn benchmark is coming from private trading (speculation, not necessarily 100bn of actual growth in the company itself) that has increased the implied valuation from 54bn at the end of jan to 100bn two weeks ago (according to the axios article)  If I understand it right those shares just go from private to public when Coinbase goes public so it seems most likely they'd stay the same price or close to it. If anything I think companies usually get a higher valuation right when they go public and then it often falls.
I think probably it will fall because 100bn seems really high for a company that only made 1.3 bn revenue in 2020. but I don't think it will fall right away on the first day. If Coinbase thought that was likely I don't think they would be wanting to list. https://www.forbes.com/advisor/investing/coinbase-ipo-direct-listing/
https://seekingalpha.com/article/4411249-coinbase-pass-upcoming-ipo-100b-valuation
